title.narrative: U.S.-China Standards & Conformity Assessment Cooperation Program, Phase V, through American National Standards Institute

description.narrative: USTDA is funding this technical assistance (TA) for a fifth series of the U.S.-China Standards and Conformity Assessment Cooperation Program (SCACP). Building upon the success of SCACP's fist four phases, this series of 20 separate and distinct workshops, to be held in different cities throughout China, will help improve China's trade capacity by familiarizing representatives from Chinese standards-setting bodies and industry with U.S. and international practices in standards-setting and conformity assessment. Phase V will continue to promote engagement between the U.S. and Chinese public and private sectors, and each workshop will have matching financial support from U.S. industry. This funding in the amount of $39,038 is being added to the U.S.-China Standards & Conformity Assessment Cooperation Program Phase V.

CAAC is the grantee for this activity, and the contractor is the American Chamber of Commerce in China fund on behalf of U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP) member companies. description.narrative: USTDA funding is enabling the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration to deliver training and program support for the USTDA-funded China Aviation Technical Assistance (ATA) Workshops Phase III. The ATA Workshops aim to strengthen the efficiency and safety of China's aviation system, while assisting U.S. companies in gaining market entry into the Chinese aviation sector. This amendment adds funding in the amount of $8,000 to transfer agreement between USTDA and the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to support FAA's participation in the USTDA-funded China Aviation Technical Assistance (ATA) Workshops Phase III. The FAA would deliver training and program support for the workshops in China.

title.narrative: Trade-Related Training Program - Airport Management and Operations Efficiency, through U.S. Chamber of Commerce

description.narrative: USTDA funding will support an Airport Management and Operations Efficiency Training Program technical assistance for the Civil Aviation Administration of China, which remains a key partner for U.S. aviation companies. The purpose of this training program is to improve the operations and management of Chinese airports to ensure that, as China's air traffic grows, air travel remains safe and efficient, and to support opportunities for U.S. suppliers of airport-related goods, services and technologies to participate in the development of China's airports. The American Chamber of Commerce in China Fund will serve as the sole source Contractor for this activity, on behalf of U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program member companies, who will present to the training program participants. This memorandum serves as a no-cost modification to the decision and project memorandum for the Airport Management and Operations Efficiency Training Program (USTDA Activity No. 2019-61003A). The change adjusts the selection criteria for participation in the U.S. and China training sessions and allows for the potential addition of training courses not already identified in the Terms of Reference.

title.narrative: U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program 2019 ATMET Phase XI, through U.S. Chamber of Commerce

description.narrative: USTDA funding is continuing support for the Air Traffic Management Executive Training (ATMET) with an eleventh phase, as part of the fifteenth phase of the U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP 2019). Launched by USTDA in 2004 as a strategic, public-private partnership, the ACP has produced significant U.S. export results on an ongoing basis, and funding of the program's next phase will ensure continuation of the high-level dialogue with the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) and its Air Traffic Management Bureau (ATMB), which oversees the procurement of air traffic management systems and equipment. This memorandum is a modification to the decision and project memoranda for the U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program 2019 Air Traffic Management Executive Training (ATMET) Phase XI (USTDA Activity No.2019-61005A). This modification changes the Program Manager subcontractor and removes one subcontractor and its training course from the Terms of Reference, consequently reducing the total grant amount to $214,624.

title.narrative: Desk Study - Calcium Carbide Off-Gas Conversion Facility, through 3E Consulting, LLC

description.narrative: This $8,000 desk study reviewed a proposal for a feasibility study to assess the technical and economic viability of a calcium carbide off-gas conversion facility, which would entail building a commercial-scale alternative fuel and chemical facility at a pre-existing calcium carbide manufacturing site. The proposed project would use LanzaTech's gas fermentation technology, which enables the conversion of calcium carbide manufacturing gas byproducts to low-carbon biofuels and chemicals. The feasibility study would help Bao Industrial Gases evaluate the viability of a commercial facility to produce bioethanol, jet fuel, and chemicals from emissions from the calcium carbide manufacturing process.

title.narrative: Desk Study - Low NOx Boiler Emission Reduction, through Innovation Network LLC

description.narrative: This desk study is reviewing a sole-sourced proposal for a feasibility study to demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of U.S. firms' low nitrogen oxide (NOx) boiler technology in meeting stringent NOx emission requirements. The proposed project will demonstrate U.S. firms' low NOx burners and Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems (CEMS), which reduce boiler emissions and enable sensitive, accurate NOx monitoring. The grantee is the Beijing Environmental Protection Bureau.

title.narrative: Desk Study - Xian Flight Delay Management, through Montgomery Consulting Group, Inc.

description.narrative: This desk study is reviewing a proposal and the Terms of Reference for technical assistance to assess the operational efficiency and capacity of Xian International Airport in China. Flight delays in China have reached record levels due to rapid growth in its air traffic volume. Thus, the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) and China's Air Traffic Management Bureau (ATMB) are prioritizing efforts to increase airport efficiency and system capacity. This technical assistance project, proposed by U.S. company members of the U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP), would showcase U.S. methodologies and tools for improving operational capacity at Xian International Airport.

The project, developed in close cooperation with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), is assisting CAACs Air Traffic Management Bureau (ATMB) to develop efficient macro-level air traffic management principles as well as improve specific processes at two of the countrys largest airports: Beijing and Guangzhou.

description.narrative: This $800,000 grant is partially funding a feasibility study (FS) and pilot project for the China Institute of Electronics (CIE), an entity under the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT). The FS is evaluating and demonstrating U.S. energy efficient technologies for a "green data center" pilot project at the Jiangsu Lake Cloud Data Center in Wuxi, China. The cost of the study is being shared by the sole-source contractor SGH Holdings, LLC. This project is a high priority for MIIT, which is planning to implement new standards for green data centers over the next two years. The FS and pilot project would serve as the model to help set these standards.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Fuel Cell Applications for Telecommunications, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $410,000 grant is partially funding a feasibility study (FS) and pilot project for Jiangsu Communications Services Company, Ltd. to evaluate fuel cell applications for telecommunications infrastructure in China. The objective of the project is to qualify fuel cell technology applications for use by the telecommunications industry in China. The fuel cell systems would be used for both backup and baseload power, replacing lead acid batteries and diesel fuel combustion generators. In addition to the pilot demonstration, the FS includes training and the development of standards for fuel cell technology growth in China.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Integrated Geospatial Transportation System, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $756,721 grant is partially funding a feasibility study (FS) and pilot project for Nanjing Sample Technology Group, Ltd. to evaluate the viability of an Integrated Geospatial Transportation System in Nanjing, China. The FS and pilot are integrating Nanjings transportation data in real-time, enabling municipal transportation managers with a more robust decision support capability. The FS and pilot project are demonstrating the benefits of this system to Nanjings key decision makers and providing a solid benchmark for the costs and challenges associated with the full-scale implementation of the transportation system. The FS and pilot are being conducted on a sole-source basis by Rolta International. The Contractor is contributing funding toward the cost of the FS and pilot. The Grantee is providing additional funding for the project.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Smart Meter Standards Development, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This activity supports the development of a smart grid in China in support of the priorities of China's National Energy Administration. The activity involves the organization and convening of a series of technical meetings in China between Chinese and U.S. smart grid experts and standards developers to develop a common electricity metering standard and to draft a roadmap for continued U.S.-China smart grid technical standards harmonization. Developing standards for smart meters would enable their widespread adoption in China, which would lower electricity costs and usage, providing economic and environmental benefits to communities and households throughout the country.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - U.S. CHINA AVIATION COOPERATION PROGRAM - PHASE III, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $1.689 million technical cooperation initiative partially funds the third phase of a public-private partnership between the U.S. and Chinese governments and aviation industries, known as the Wright Brothers Partnership U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP). Lead project elements include technical and managerial training for Chinese aviation officials and airline representatives, technical assistance on aircraft continued airworthiness, maintainability and certification training, market assessment of the regional and general aviation in China and the preliminary study of an Air Traffic Flow Management System in China. This integrated program is led by U.S. industry members of the ACP and the Federal Aviation Administration in conjunction with officials of the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China (CAAC) and other stakeholders in the Chinese aviation industry. The initiative aims to promote high-level dialogue between the U.S. and Chinese governments in aviation cooperation and U.S. commercial interests in China's rapidly expanding aviation sector. The grantee for the project is the CAAC and the contractor is the American Chamber of Commerce in China Fund (AmCham) on behalf of the ACP member organizations.

description.narrative: USTDA funding of a $198,330 supports technical assistance (TA) to help China improve its ability to accurately predict and monitor earthquake aftershocks and landslides. This TA focuses on Sichuan Province, the area most impacted by the May 2008 earthquake, and entails a two-year training program for officials from the China Earthquake Administration (CEA) and the China Geological Survey (CGS). A team of research seismologists led by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) conducts this training, which also involves installation of pilot aftershock and landslide monitoring systems and operational training on their use.

title.narrative: Desk Study - ACP-CAAC AIRPORT DEPARTMENT HUBBING STUDY, through Montgomery Consulting Group, Inc.

description.narrative: This $5,000 Desk Study reviews a preliminary concept proposal for a feasibility study (FS) analyzing hubbing structure at major Chinese airports in Beijing and Shanghai. Currently, Chinese airports have limited capacity for minimizing connection times, optimizing runway and airspace use, reducing physical distance between arriving and departing flights, and efficiently managing the processing of passengers through security. As a result, passengers on U.S.-China flight routes often must pass through third country hubs on their way to secondary Chinese cities, leading to higher costs and reduced competitiveness for U.S. and Chinese carriers. An FS is neccessary to best assess and ameliorate these challenges in China's aviation industry to improve airport capacity and expand opportunities for U.S. and Chinese airlines.

description.narrative: USTDA funding of $325,000 is supporting the U.S.- China Aviation Symposium, a two and half-day conference held in Beijing China in late 2013. This symposium builds upon themes from previous U.S.- China aviation events, with focus on key areas such as air traffic management and safety, emissions reduction, air traffic control capacity and efficiency, general aviation, air navigation and communications systems, air cargo infrastructure and green airport development. It targets up to 250 attendees, including senior government officials from the United States and China, as well as representatives from the U.S. aviation industry.

title.narrative: Technical Symposium - Senior Health Executive Training Program, through Telecom/Telematique, Inc.

description.narrative: The funding amount of $271,610 is partially supporting a training program for Chinese senior healthcare executives to introduce them to U.S. health IT applications, medical equipment and services, advanced management techniques, and healthcare policy initiatives. The program is also being supported by members of USTDAs Health Cooperation Program (HCP), which is responsible for developing the curriculum and funding an additional $320,000 for the cost of the training. The training program is being undertaken in conjunction with the Chinese Ministry of Health (MOH), Harvard University, and Tsinghua University in Beijing.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Fuel cell Applications for Telecommunications, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $410,000 grant is partially funding a Feasibility Study (FS) and pilot project for Jiangsu Communications Services Company, Ltd. to evaluate fuel cell applications for telecommunications infrastructure in China. The objective of the proposed project is to qualify fuel cell technology applications for use by the telecommunications industry in China. The fuel cell systems would be used for both backup and baseload power, replacing lead acid batteries and diesel fuel combustion generators. In addition to the pilot demonstration, the FS includes training and the development of standards for fuel cell technology growth in China.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Integrated Geospatial Transportation System, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $756,721 grant is partially funding a Feasibility Study (FS) and pilot project for Nanjing Sample Technology Group, Ltd. to evaluate the viability of an Integrated Geospatial Transportation System in Nanjing, China. The FS and pilot integrate Nanjings transportation data in real-time, enabling municipal transportation managers with a more robust decision support capability. The FS and pilot project are demonstrating the benefits of this system to Nanjings key decision makers and providing a solid benchmark for the costs and challenges associated with the full-scale implementation of the transportation system. The FS is being conducted on a sole source basis by Rolta International. The Contractor is contributing $1,604,000 or 54% toward the cost of the FS and Pilot. The Grantee is providing an additional $625,000 or 21% in funding for the project.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - State Grid Smart Grid Standards Development, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $442,380 technical assistance (TA) helps the China State Grid Electric Power Research Institute develop Chinese standards for smart grid infrastructure that are appropriate for China and harmonized with U.S. standards. Developing standards for the smart grid would enable its widespread implementation in China, which would lower electricity costs and usage, providing economic and environmental benefits to communities and households throughout the country.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Feasibility Study and Pilot Project Integrated Real Time Water Monitoring System, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: USTDA is contributing $589,466 to partially fund a Feasibility Study (FS) for the Changjiang Water Resources Commission (CWRC) of China on an Integrated Real Time Water Monitoring System. The FS and pilot assess the technical and financial feasibility of installing a water monitoring system in the Han River Basin. Such a system would positively impact the environment of the entire Tangtze River Basin as well as help ensure clean drinking water for large populations in Northern China. CWRC and the Sutron Corporation (Sterling, VA), the sole source contractor, are sharing costs on the FS.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Pilot and Feasibility Study Demand Response System, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: USTDA is contributing $660,000 to partially fund a feasibility study for China's State Grid Electric Power Research Institute to assess the economic and technical feasibility of implementing demand response systems in China's electric grid and to help develop a smart grid implementation strategy for China. Developing a smart grid would lower electricity costs and usage, providing economic and environmental benefits to communities and households throughout China. Honeywell International, Inc and AECOM are sharing the costs of the study.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program Phase VII, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: USTDA funding of $876,221 continues support for the U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP) with a seventh phase. This strategic, multi-program, public-private partnership that USTDA launched in 2004 has produced significant developmental and U.S. export results. Continuation of the program ensures an ongoing high-level dialogue with the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC), which has promoted the interests of the U.S. aviation sector in China. Phase VII includes CAAC executive management training and air traffic management executive training, components that were highly successful in previous phases, as well as an Air Traffic Flow Management Playbook.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - U.S. - China Aviation Cooperation Program Phase IV, FAA Transfer Funds, through U.S. Government - Department of Transportation

description.narrative: USTDA funding of $68,883 enables the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration to deliver training and program support to the sixth phase of the Executive Management Training Program and provide technical assistance in the development of an Air Traffic Flow Management (ATFM) Playbook and Ground Delay Program, conducted under the seventh phase of the U.S.-China Aviation Cooperation Program (ACP). This training and technical assistance aims to build strong relationships between the U.S. and Chinese aviation sectors and assist the Chinese aviation market to continue to expand.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Public Infrastructure Emergency Mangagement System Project, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $613,241 feasibility study (FS) provides the China Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) a technical plan demonstrating the feasibility of a safety solution for Chinese dams and reservoirs. The Dams and Reservoirs Emergency Management System project would increase China's ability to monitor and react to dam and reservoir events, thereby protecting lives, property, the environment and economic activity through timely emergency response and disaster mitigation. MWR and Intergraph Corporation (Madison, AL), the sole source contractor, are sharing costs on the project.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Shandong Environmental Emergency Response System FS, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $346,634 USTDA grant to the Shandong Environmental Protection Bureau funds a feasibility study on the development of an environmental early warning and emergency response command system for Shandong Province. The system would improve environmental real-time data monitoring and analysis; establish an advanced emergency operations and incident response command center; and deploy an effective early warning system for environmental hazards at the provincial, county and municipal levels. Successful completion of this project could avert environmental disasters in Shandong and serve as a model for the development of environmental response networks across China.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - U.S. - China Legal Advisory Assistance: Anti-Monopoly Law, Phase II, through Government of China (P.R.C.)

description.narrative: This $150,000 Technical Assistance (TA) supports U.S. industry and government objectives through an integrated program of four (4) workshops that address China's implementation of its Anti-Monopoly Law (AML). This TA trains Chinese officials on how the provisions of the AML and eventual implementing regulations are best applied to ensure outcomes that promote the competitive process and secure non-discriminatory treatment for all market participants. The TA Contractor is the U.S. Chamber of Commerce (Washington, DC); the TA Grantee is the American Chamber of Commerce (Beijing, China).
